original_data.question: A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with difficulty breathing and a sensation that her heart was racing for the past 3 days. She adds that she has lost weight over the last 7 weeks, despite a good appetite, and is anxious most of the time with difficulty sleeping at night. She has smoked 10 cigarettes per day for the past 15 years. Her blood pressure is 100/55 mmHg, temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), and pulse is irregular with a rate of 140–150/min. On physical examination she is thin, frail, and appears anxious. Her palms are sweaty and there are fine tremors on extension of both hands. She has a palpable smooth thyroid mass. Examination of the eyes reveals bilateral exophthalmos. An electrocardiogram is obtained and shown in the picture. Which of the following has a strong positive correlation with this patient’s heart rhythm?

model_response: This electrocardiogram shows a rapid, irregularly irregular rhythm. The QRS complexes are narrow, suggesting a ventricular origin of the arrhythmia. There are no clearly discernible P waves, but the irregularity of the QRS complexes suggests an irregular ventricular response. The QRS axis and intervals are normal. The patient has atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. The irregularity of the rhythm suggests a lack of AV synchrony.  The absence of clearly discernible P waves on the electrocardiogram makes it difficult to know whether the patient has underlying heart disease. The patient's symptoms, however, suggest that she has a hyperthyroid state. Thyrotoxicosis is a cause of atrial fibrillation and may be associated with exophthalmos and a palpable thyroid mass. The irregularly irregular rhythm suggests that the patient is having episodes of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. The absence of AV synchrony increases the risk of cardiac failure. The patient's age, sex, and smoking history make her a candidate for coronary artery disease. The absence of chest pain and the electrocardiogram findings make acute myocardial infarction unlikely. The patient's symptoms, however, suggest that she has a hyperthyroid state. Thyrotoxicosis is a cause of atrial fibrillation and may be associated with exophthalmos and a palpable thyroid mass. The irregularly irregular rhythm suggests that the patient is having episodes of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Difficult or labored breathing.

The process in which specialized SENSORY RECEPTOR CELLS transduce peripheral stimuli (physical or chemical) into NERVE IMPULSES which are then transmitted to the various sensory centers in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM.
The hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Decrease in existing BODY WEIGHT.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
A question about whether an individual has or had a good appetite.
Feelings or emotions of dread, apprehension, and impending disaster but not disabling as with ANXIETY DISORDERS.
The dimension of the physical universe which, at a given place, orders the sequence of events. (McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Scientific and Technical Terms, 6th ed)

An abnormality of sleep including such phenomena as 1) insomnia/hypersomnia, 2) non-restorative sleep, 3) sleep schedule disorder, 4) excessive daytime somnolence, 5) sleep apnea, and 6) restlessness. [HPO:curators]
The time in every 24 hour period when it is dark.
Roll of dried and finely cut TOBACCO leaves wrapped in a cylinder of thin paper used for SMOKING.
Occurring or done each day.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
Lacking perfect symmetry or evenness.
The act of ascertaining or fixing the value or worth of something.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Feelings or emotions of dread, apprehension, and impending disaster but not disabling as with ANXIETY DISORDERS.
The palm family of order Arecales, subclass Arecidae, class Liliopsida.

Cyclical movement of a body part that can represent either a physiologic process or a manifestation of disease. Intention or action tremor, a common manifestation of CEREBELLAR DISEASES, is aggravated by movement. In contrast, resting tremor is maximal when there is no attempt at voluntary movement, and occurs as a relatively frequent manifestation of PARKINSON DISEASE.
To increase in length or duration.
The distal part of the arm beyond the wrist in humans and primates, that includes the palm, fingers, and thumb.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
The organ of sight constituting a pair of globular organs made up of a three-layered roughly spherical structure specialized for receiving and responding to light.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Abnormal protrusion of both eyes; may be caused by endocrine gland malfunction, malignancy, injury, or paralysis of the extrinsic muscles of the eye.
A study that evaluates the effect of a treatment on cardiac electrical activity, as assessed by electrocardiography.
An image recorded by a camera.
Involving advantage or good.

The degree to which two or more quantities or events are linearly associated, a statistical relation between two or more variables such that systematic changes in the value of one variable are accompanied by systematic changes in the others.
The recurrent, measured movements (rhythm) of a beating heart.
